metadata.case_name: Indian Chemical Products Ltd. v. State of Orissa

facts.text: On November 29, 1947, the Indian Chemical Products, Ltd., a limited company, was incorporated having its registered offices in Baripada, Mayurbhanj and in the town of Calcutta. Its authorised capital is Rs. 25 lakhs divided into 25,000 shares of Rs. 100 each.

The company has seven shareholders. The Maharaja of Mayurbhanj subscribed and paid for 7,500 shares. The remaining six shareholders hold 150 shares only. All the shareholders are signatories to the memorandum of association of the company.
The 7,500 shares were held by the Maharaja in his capacity as ruler of the State of Mayurbhanj.

State of Mayurbhanj was one of the feudatory States of Orissa under the suzerainty of the British Crown. As from August 15, 1947, with the declaration of independence the paramountcy of the British Crown lapsed.

On October 17, 1948, the Maharaja of Mayurbhanj signed an agreement for the merger of the State with the Dominion. By art. 1 of this agreement, the Maharaja completely ceded to the Dominion his sovereignty over the State of Mayurbhanj as from November 9, 1948. Article 4 allowed the Maharaja to retain ownership of his private properties only as distinct from State properties.
On and from November 9, 1948, as a necessary consequence of the cesser of sovereignty all the public properties of the State including the 7,500 shares in the company vested in the Dominion.

As from January 1, 1949, the Government of India delegated to the Government of Orissa the power to administer the territories of the merged State under s. 3(2) of the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act 1947.

On August 1, 1949, the States Merger (Governors' Provinces) Order, 1949 came into force, and in consequence of s. 5(1) of the Order, all property vested in the Dominion Government for purposes of governance of the merged State became vested in the Government of Orissa, unless for central purposes.
By a certificate dated November 10, 1953, the Government of India declared that the 7,500 shares were not held for central purposes.
Under the Constitution which came into force on January 26, 1950, the territories of the merged State were included in the State of Orissa.
State of Orissa claims title to the shares vested by operation of law and also based on formal instrument of transfer executed by the Maharaja.
On March 16, 1950, the Government of Orissa lodged the share scrip and the transfer deed with the company, and requested it to make the necessary changes in the share register.

The Government as also the Maharaja, through his agent, the Imperial Bank of India, repeatedly requested the company to register the Secretary to the Government of Orissa, Finance Department as the holder of the shares in place of the Maharaja.
There was protracted correspondence in the matter for over three years and eventually on May 16, 1953, the board of directors of the company refused to register the transfer.

On December 1, 1953, Sri S. K. Mandal, attorney for the State of Orissa, requested the company to record the name of the State as the owner of the shares in the share register, but the company declined to do so.

On February 9, 1955, the State of Orissa filed an application under s. 38 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 in the High Court of Orissa asking for rectification of the share register by inserting its name as the holder of the shares in place of the Maharaja. The company and the Maharaja were impleaded as respondents.
The application was contested by the company only. On November 22, 1956, Ray, J. allowed the application.
On September 13, 1957, Ray, J. passed a supplemental order directing the filing of the notice of rectification with the Registrar within a fortnight.
On September 5, 1960, a Division Bench of the High Court dismissed the appeal preferred by the company.
The company appeals to this Court on a certificate granted by the High Court.

Both courts concurrently held that: 1. the title to the shares vested in the State of Orissa by operation of law; 2. the refusal of the board of directors to register the transfer was mala fide; 3. the State of Orissa was entitled to rectification of the share register and a proper case for the exercise of the Court's jurisdiction under s. 38 had been made out; 4. the petition was not liable to be dismissed on the ground that the State had asked the company to register the name of the Secretary.

The appellate Court also held that under the articles of association of the company the board of directors had no power to refuse registration of a transfer where the transfer was by operation of law.
The transfer deed was duly stamped and complied with all the formalities required by law.

In spite of the fact that the State had filed with the company a certificate of the Collector of Stamp Revenue, West Bengal, that no stamp duty was payable on the transfer, the company raised the objection that the transfer deed must be stamped. To avoid this objection, the Government stamped the deed and again lodged it with the company.
For over three years, the directors delayed registration of the transfer on frivolous pretexts.

Before the High Court, the company asserted that the registration was refused because the Maharaja was under an obligation to execute an agreement conferring valuable rights on the company and the State had failed to honour this obligation. Reliance placed on cl. 6 of the company's memorandum of association.

Clause 6 shows that there was a proposal between the parties to enter into an agreement, but there was no concluded agreement between them, nor was there any binding obligation on the Maharaja to execute an agreement.

By its letter dated March 17, 1953, the company assured the Imperial Bank that the registration would be effected shortly. Nevertheless, on May 16, 1953 the directors capriciously refused to register the transfer.

legal_issues.text: Whether title to the 7,500 shares vested in the State of Orissa by operation of law consequent to constitutional changes.
Whether under the articles of association, particularly Art. 11, the board of directors had power to refuse registration of the transfer/devolution of shares where by operation of law.
Whether the refusal of the board of directors to register the transfer was mala fide.
Whether the State of Orissa was entitled to rectification of the share register under s. 38 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913.
Whether the petition was liable to be dismissed because the State asked to register the Secretary as shareholder.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under Art. 11 of the articles of association, the Board of Directors shall have full right to refuse to register the transfer of any share or shares to any person without showing any cause.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 11 of company's articles; cl. 6 of memorandum

petitioner_arguments.text: The registration was refused because the Maharaja was under obligation to execute agreement and State failed to honour it.
Petition liable to be dismissed as State asked to register Secretary, not State itself.

respondent_arguments.text: Title to shares vested in State by operation of law due to merger and constitutional changes; directors bound to register unless restrictive provision.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Merger agreement; Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act 1947 s.3(2); States Merger Order 1949 s.5(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Devolution by operation of law is transmission, not transfer; Art. 11 applies only to transfers by act of parties.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Table A regulations, Indian Companies Act 1913

respondent_arguments.text: Even on transfer deed basis, refusal was mala fide; transfer complied with formalities.

court_reasoning.text: The finding that shares held by Maharaja as ruler is supported; by merger and constitutional changes, shares vested in Dominion then Orissa by operation of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public properties devolved on succeeding sovereign.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 11 refers to transfers by act of parties; devolution by operation of law is transmission, not within Art. 11; restrictive provision strictly construed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Table A distinguishes transfer (instrument by both parties) from transmission by operation of law.

court_reasoning.text: Refusal mala fide: delayed on frivolous pretexts, stamped after objection, reason given was afterthought, no concluded agreement under cl.6; power must be exercised reasonably and in good faith.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Directors cannot refuse to coerce agreement.

court_reasoning.text: State entitled to rectification under s.38: name omitted without reason, default in entering cessation of Maharaja.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction beneficial, to be liberally exercised.

court_reasoning.text: No objection taken by company to registering Secretary; later letter called for State as owner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Company refused despite clear request for State.

holdings.text: Title to shares vested in State of Orissa by operation of law.
Directors had no power under articles to refuse registration of devolution by operation of law.
Refusal to register even the transfer deed was mala fide.
State entitled to rectification under s.38.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Bentham Mills Spinning Company
precedents_cited.relevance: James L.J.: Table A distinguishes 'transmission' (by operation of law) from 'transfer' (by act of parties).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Rectification of register; power to refuse transmission only on death/insolvency.

statutes_cited.name: States Merger (Governors' Provinces) Order, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of property in Orissa Government.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Re involuntary transfer by court sale (noted but no opinion).

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed with costs. High Court order for rectification of share register upheld; directors prevented State from membership for 16 years on frivolous objections.
outcome.relief_granted: Rectification of share register in favour of State of Orissa

key_quotes.text: "In Table A the word transmission is put in contradistinction to the word transfer. One means a transfer by the act of the parties, the other means transmission by devolution of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes transmission from transfer, key to Art.11 interpretation.

key_quotes.text: The directors must exercise this power reasonably and in good faith. The Court can control their discretion if they act capriciously or in bad faith.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The jurisdiction created by S. 38 is very beneficial and should be liberally exercised.
key_quotes.speaker: court
